43.name: where_to_report_scams
43.title: Where to report scams
43.metaDescription: Use USA.gov’s scam reporting tool to identify a scam and help you find the right government agency or consumer organization to report it.

45.name: phishing_scam
45.title: Phishing scam
45.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

You receive a scam email or text message that looks like it’s from a company you trust. It asks you to verify your bank account, debit card, or credit card number.

Report this scam

Report phishing attempts to the Federal Trade Commission.

You can also forward phishing messages to the Anti-Phishing Working Group at reportphishing@apwg.org and to your cell provider at 7726 (SPAM).

 

Learn more

Learn how to recognize and avoid phishing scams.
45.optionName: Phishing (scam email or text pretending to be from a real company)

46.name: federal_tax_or_irs_scam
46.title: Federal tax or IRS scam
46.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Imposters may pose as the IRS or other government agencies claiming that you owe taxes. They ask you to pay them by purchasing a gift card or wiring money. 

Report this scam

Report to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. Forward email messages that claim to be from the IRS to phishing@irs.gov.

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI and to the Federal Trade Commission.

Learn more

Understand more about imposter scams and how to keep yourself safe.
46.optionName: Your federal taxes or the IRS

47.name: rental_scam
47.title: Rental scam
47.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Scammers advertise apartments or vacation rentals that they don’t own or manage or that don’t actually exist. 

Report this scam

Report online to the Federal Trade Commission.

You can also report to your local law enforcement and the website or publication where the rental ad was posted.

Learn more

Learn the signs of a rental listing scam.

48.name: other_scams
48.title: Other scams
48.body:
Based on your answers

Report scams to the Federal Trade Commission online.

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

49.name: romance_scam_(catfishing)
49.title: Romance scam (catfishing)
49.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Scammers use flattery and fake photographs and background stories to gain your affection. They then ask you to send money or gift cards.

Report this scam

Report online to the Federal Trade Commission.

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Get tips from the FTC to avoid getting taken advantage of by romance scammers.

51.name: other_imposter_scams
51.title: Other imposter scams
51.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Imposters pretend to be someone you know or a person in a position of authority. They often come with an urgent request for money.

Report this scam

Report to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Understand more about imposter scams and how to keep yourself safe.
51.optionName: A trusted company, loved one, or a government office

52.name: social_security_scam
52.title: Social Security scam
52.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Scammers pose as the Social Security Administration or as a government employee. They may ask you to pay money or attempt to get your personal information.

Report this scam

Report to the Social Security Administration. 

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Learn how to recognize and avoid Social Security-related scams.
52.optionName: Your Social Security number or benefits

53.name: imposter_scam
53.title: Imposter scam
53.optionName: Imposter (someone claiming to be someone they’re not)

54.name: another_type_of_identity_theft
54.title: Another type of identity theft
54.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Identity theft happens when someone uses your personal or financial information to commit fraud.

Report this scam

Report to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Learn the warning signs and how to protect yourself from identity theft.

55.name: other_types_of_medical_identity_scams
55.title: Other types of medical identity scams
55.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Someone uses your personal information to get health care and submit claims to your insurance provider.

Report this scam

Report to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Learn how to avoid medical identity theft.
55.optionName: Another type of medical identity theft

56.name: medicare_or_medicaid_identity_theft
56.title: Medicare or Medicaid identity theft
56.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Someone uses your personal information to submit health claims to Medicare or Medicaid.

Report this scam

Report online to the Health and Human Services Office of Inspector General Hotline. Or report by phone at 1-800-447-8477 (1-800-HHS-TIPS).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Learn how to avoid medical identity theft.

58.name: unemployment_identity_theft
58.title: Unemployment identity theft
58.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

A person uses your name, Social Security number, and other information to apply for unemployment benefits.

Report this scam

Report to your state’s labor department. Find their contact information in this list.

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Find out how to protect your finances after an unemployment scam.
58.optionName: Use your personal information to get unemployment benefits?

59.name: job_related_identity_theft
59.title: Job-related identity theft
59.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

A person uses your name, Social Security number, and personal information to apply for a job. 

Report this scam

Report to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Get information from the IRS about what to do if you experience employment-related identity theft.
59.optionName: Use your personal information to get a job?

61.name: tax_related_identity_theft
61.title: Tax-related identity theft
61.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Scammers use your Social Security number and other personal information to file a fraudulent tax return. 

Report this scam

Report to both the IRS and Federal Trade Commission (FTC). Report to the IRS using Form 14039. Report to the FTC online or by phone at 1-877-438-4338.

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Understand more about imposter scams and how to keep yourself safe.

63.name: other_housing_scam
63.title: Other housing scam
63.body:
Based on your answers

Report scams to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

64.name: moving_scam_(across_state_lines)
64.title: Moving scam (across state lines)
64.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Some moving companies use fraudulent practices such as demanding cash up front or requiring you to pay additional money before they’ll give you your belongings.

Report this scam

If you have an issue with a move across state lines, file a complaint with the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration.

You can also file a report using the Better Business Bureau Scam Tracker. 

Learn more

Learn how to spot moving fraud before it happens.

65.name: moving_scam_(within_the_same_state)
65.title: Moving scam (within the same state)
65.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Some moving companies use fraudulent practices such as demanding cash up front or requiring you to pay additional money before they’ll give you your belongings.

Report this scam

If you have a complaint about a move within your same city or state, contact your state or local regulatory authority.

You can also file a report using the Better Business Bureau Scam Tracker. 

Learn more

Learn how to spot moving fraud before it happens.
65.optionName: Local or within the same state

67.name: mortgage_or_foreclosure_scam
67.title: Mortgage or foreclosure scam
67.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Scammers may offer to "help" you make your mortgage payments, but they’re just trying to take your money. 

Report this scam

Report to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

Learn more

Learn about the types of mortgage relief scams.

69.name: other_banking_scam
69.title: Other banking scam
69.body:
Based on your answers

Report scams to the Federal Trade Commission online, or by phone at 1-877-382-4357 (9:00 AM - 8:00 PM, ET).

Also, report any scam that happened online to the FBI.

70.name: automatic_withdrawal_scam
70.title: Automatic withdrawal scam
70.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

A scam company sets up automatic withdrawals from your bank account for you to qualify for a free trial or to collect a prize.

Report this scam

Contact your bank to report and stop unauthorized automatic withdrawals from your account. 

Learn more

Learn about managing withdrawals and debit payments from your bank account.
70.optionName: Automated withdrawal made from your account

71.name: unsolicited_check_scam
71.title: Unsolicited check scam
71.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

A scammer sends you a check for no reason. If you cash it, you may be authorizing the purchase of items or signing up for a loan you didn’t ask for.

Report this scam

Report fake checks you receive by mail to the U.S. Postal Inspection Service.

Learn more

Find out what to do if you receive an unsolicited check.

72.name: fake_check_scam
72.title: Fake check scam
72.body:
Based on your answers

About this scam

Someone sends you a check for more than the amount they owe and they ask you to refund the difference. But the check was fake, so you have to pay your bank the amount of the check and lose any money you gave the scammer.

Report this scam

Report fake checks you receive by mail to the U.S. Postal Inspection Service.

Learn more

Learn how to avoid and deal with fake check scams.

74.name: what_type_of_scam_do_you_need_to_report?
74.title: What type of scam do you need to report?
74.body: What type of scam do you need to report?
74.metaDescription: Just answer a few questions with USAGov's scam reporting tool to find out where to report a scam and how to keep yourself safe.
